newsitem.title: JAPAN: JAPAN CONSTRUCTION BOND YIELDS KEEP RISING.
newsitem.headline: JAPAN CONSTRUCTION BOND YIELDS KEEP RISING.

text.p: Yields on straight bonds issued by second-tier construction firms rose in Japan's corporate bond market on Thursday due to lingering concerns about the financial health of the firms, bond traders said.

Fujita Corp's 3.0 percent straight bond due September 2001, rated triple B minus by the Japan Bond Research Institute (JBRI), was offered at a yield of 9.77 percent, more than 800 basis points above the four-year interest-rate swap (IRS) rate of around 1.55/1.59 percent, traders said.
The Fujita bond had been offered at 9.43 percent on late Wednesday.

A 2.95 percent straight bond issued by JDC Corp due July 2002 was offered at a yield of 10.34 percent, over 800 basis points above the five-year IRS rate of around 1.80/1.84 percent. No quotes were available on Wednesday.
"Offer quotes of construction company bonds continue to climb. They are offering high yields but nobody seems to be willing to buy them," said a trader at a Japanese brokerage house.
Share prices of construction firms also fell sharply in the Tokyo stock market on Thursday.
Fujita ended down 21 yen at 95 yen, after falling to a record low of 92 yen. JDC closed down 14 yen at a record low of 82 yen.
Concerns about construction firms pushed the Nikkei 225 stock average down and helped lift Japanese government bond (JGB) prices and the dollar on Thursday afternoon.
Bond traders said investors became increasingly worried about second-tier construction companies after two listed general contractors, Tokai Kogyo Co and Tada Corp, virtually went bankrupt in July.
